author: By Danielle Friedman
title: Don’t Let Rain Cancel Your Workout
description: Fans of soggy weather workouts swear by their benefits. Here’s how to exercise in a drizzle smartly and safely, and maybe even enjoy it.
content: When the skies open, most people run for cover. But some run for fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Marry Me Chicken
description: More swoon-worthy dishes: brussels sprouts Caesar, chile-oil noodles with cilantro, and oozy chocolate lava cake.
content: If you’re on TikTok (or have a youth in your home that’s on the app), you may have heard of marry me chicken, a dish so delicious it has motivated countless feet-draggers to drop their doubts and pop the question. (You can read Christina Morales’s fun piece on the subject in The New York Times.) There are hundreds of variations on this recipe, but ours, from Naz Deravian, features sautéed chicken cutlets with a creamy sun-dried tomato, Parmesan and basil sauce (above). Even tying the knot is not your goal, this deluxe meal will make anyone at the table fall head over heels in love with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: A Lake Turned to a Hot ‘Soup.’ Then the River Dolphins Died.
description: The carcasses of at least 125 Amazon river dolphins have been found floating or beached after temperatures in Lake Tefé, Brazil, reached a staggering 39.1 degrees Celsius.
content: Their pink bodies began to wash ashore last month, startling locals and scientists in the remote Amazon town of Tefé, Brazil, who had never seen anything like it. A crippling drought had sucked parts of tributaries flowing into the Amazon River nearly dry, causing some water routes to become impassible and turning other shallow areas into a hot bath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: It’s Getting Harder to Be Poor in New York
description: City services for the poor are lagging under Mayor Eric Adams. Also, Central Park’s Great Lawn, damaged in a concert, is closing six weeks early for maintenance.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at how it’s taking longer for the city to provide some critical services for vulnerable New Yorkers. We’ll also find out why the Great Lawn in Central Park has been closed for the winter — six weeks earlier than usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Review: Robert Gober Conjures America
description: The artist, displaying his own work along with his idiosyncratic holdings, invites rumination on the state of the nation at Demisch Danant gallery.
content: The artist Robert Gober must be a consummate shopper. “Cows at a Pond,” his fragmentary but resonant portrait of the United States at Demisch Danant, has been curated entirely from his own possessions. That is, from his own art and work by other artists living and dead that he has collected, combined with selections from the ephemera and Americana he has accumulated over the years, including some of his household furniture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Suddenly, It Will Be Autumn for Much of the U.S. This Weekend
description: The fall season has been off to a late start in the central and Northeastern United States, but chilly air this weekend could be a jolt, especially to those who endured a sweltering summer.
content: Oct. 1 should have been a cool and crisp Sunday in the Twin Cities, the kind in which a temperature reading around the daily average high of 56.7 degrees would have been perfect for finding the right pumpkin to carve or getting lost in a corn maze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: False Advertising Suit Against McDonald’s and Wendy’s Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn said he had not found that the fast-food chains sold burgers that were smaller than the ones they featured in advertisements.
content: A federal judge in Brooklyn has dismissed a lawsuit against Wendy’s and McDonald’s that accused the companies of exaggerating the size of their burgers in advertisements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Dish Is First Company to Be Fined by F.C.C. Over Space Junk Rule
description: Dish, the television provider, failed to move its dead satellite into a higher orbit, where it would pose little threat to active satellites, the agency announced. The company agreed to pay a $150,000 fine.
content: With a growing number of satellites orbiting the Earth and space junk increasingly becoming a concern, the Federal Communications Commission announced on Tuesday that it had for the first time fined a company for failing to properly dispose of a dead satellite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Ivor Prickett
title: When Russia Is a Neighbor, Self-Defense Is Everyone’s Concern
description: Even though it’s now part of NATO, a wary Finland still requires men to serve their country. Women can volunteer, and many do.
content: The facade of the apartment building was blown off, the remains sagging to one side. Working together, the military police, the emergency services, the fire department and the explosives team cordoned off the scene, swept for other explosives, disarmed one, and searched for those still alive in the rubble with sniffer dogs, while removing the wounded and the dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: This Store-Bought Spice Blend Makes Everything Taste Better
description: Shichimi togarashi, beloved in Japanese cuisine, is more than just a final seasoning; its multidimensional savoriness can transform your cooking, too.
content: At Sushi Yoko in Norcross, Ga., as at Japanese restaurants across the world, each booth has a red-capped bottle of shichimi togarashi, the seven-spice blend that makes food taste spicy, savory, nutty and electric all at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Caldwell
title: The U.S. Has a New Set of Tools for Bullying the World
description: How the global economy became weaponized.
content: The greatest collateral damage from last year’s Russian invasion of Ukraine has been to various Western European members of NATO, which suddenly find their national interests subordinated to those of their strongest ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Police Identify Victims and Seek Cause of Deadly Bus Crash Near Venice
description: More than 20 people were killed and several were in intensive care after a bus crashed through a guardrail and onto an empty street below.
content: The day after a bus crashed near Venice, killing 20 tourists from countries including Ukraine and Germany as well as its Italian driver, the authorities identified eight victims and said they were working to find the cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: N.Y.P.D. Sergeant Shown on Video Pummeling Man Is Charged With Assault
description: Sgt. Christian Zapata was demoted after he punched a man who asked him and other officers to put on masks, prosecutors said.
content: A New York City police officer who responded to a call reporting a distraught teenager repeatedly punched the boyfriend of the boy’s mother, a prosecutor from the Manhattan district attorney’s office said at the officer’s arraignment on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Manitoba Elects a First Nations Provincial Premier, a Canadian First
description: Wab Kinew, an Anishinaabe politician who leads the New Democratic Party, will replace the conservative Heather Stefanson as Manitoba’s leader.
content: Manitoba became the first province in Canada to elect a government headed by a First Nations member on Tuesday, with a win by the left-of-center New Democratic Party, led by Wab Kinew, who is Anishinaabe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachel Quester, Rachelle Bonja, Mary Wilson, Alex Stern, Lisa Chow, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Ouster of House Speaker Kevin McCarthy
description: For the first time in American history, the House of Representatives has voted to remove its leader.
content: The vote on Tuesday to remove Representative Kevin McCarthy as speaker of the House of Representatives has left the chamber mired in chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Small Moments From Your Life Do You Think About Often?
description: To accompany our 100-Word Narrative Contest, we’re inviting you to write about your memories — with inspiration from last year’s winners.
content: What small moments from your life do you think about often? Scenes from your childhood? An experience with your friends or family, or maybe a stranger? A memory that makes you laugh — or breaks your heart, or fills you with regret?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barbara Chai
title: When Did You Watch Your First Scary Movie? We Want to Know.
description: Halloween season is here, and we’re asking readers to share their memories of the first scary film that kept them up at night, and how old they were at the time.
content: It was a rite of passage. You were young and you got to stay up late, curl up on the sofa with a snugly blanket and buttered popcorn, and you watched Linda Blair get possessed by a demon in “The Exorcist.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: interlocutor
description: This word has appeared in 42 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word interlocutor has appeared in 42 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 17 in the Opinion essay “Debate Doesn’t Have to Be Divisive” by Peter Coy:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Exorcist: Believer’ Review: Double the Possession, Half the Fun
description: Two young girls bring something nasty home from the woods in this too-busy, uninvolving possession movie.
content: A half century ago, the great William Friedkin directed “The Exorcist,” blowing box-office records and audiences’ minds. Now David Gordon Green, not content with mining the “Halloween” franchise for a trilogy of uneven follow-ups, has returned to visit the same fate on one of the highest-grossing films of the 1970s. Kicking off with “The Exorcist: Believer,” this latest recycling project will continue with “The Exorcist: Deceiver,” planned for 2025. No word yet on the third.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Sarah Vaughan
description: All it might take is a second and a half of hearing her sing to make your spine tingle or your heart drop. Opera singers, jazz vocalists, writers and Vaughan’s biographer share their favorites.
content: For over a year, we’ve been rooting through jazz history five minutes at a time. We’ve covered favorites by Ornette Coleman, Mary Lou Williams, New Orleans’s jazz greats and many others. Now let’s turn our attention to a vocalist who epitomized — but couldn’t be contained by — jazz: Sarah Vaughan, “The Divine One,” owner of perhaps the most impressive vocal instrument in recorded history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: What Kind of Year Has It Been for Gardeners? An Aggravating One.
description: From spongy moth caterpillars to torrential rains, this garden season has been plagued by one challenge after another.
content: The linen closet did not hold nearly enough sheets to blunt the vengeance of a late-May freeze that turned umbrella-like Astilboides leaves into alien life-forms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Don’t Call Ibram X. Kendi a Grifter
description: To delight in his failure as the head of the Center for Antiracist Research is small.
content: The headlines lately have been full of the news that Ibram X. Kendi of Boston University has dismissed about half of the staff of the Center for Antiracist Research, which he has headed since 2020. Meanwhile, the university has initiated an investigation into the operations of the organization, which has taken in tens of millions of dollars in funding with almost no research to show for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Alan Murray to Step Down as C.E.O. of Fortune
description: Mr. Murray, who has been at the publication since 2014, will leave his role at the end of April.
content: Alan Murray, the chief executive of Fortune, announced on Wednesday that he would step down next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: Sex, Thugs and Kidneys: ‘Bargain’ Bids to Be the Next ‘Squid Game’
description: A new Paramount+ thriller depicts a fight for survival amid sex scams, organ auctions and earthquakes. Like other Korean dramas, it is really about class.
content: In “Bargain,” a new dystopian South Korean series on Paramount+, a man shows up at a hotel far from the city to consummate a deal. He is to pay a young woman for sex; the price is steep because she claims to be a virgin. But wait: It turns out she actually works for a criminal organ-auctioning operation, and the guy is about to unwillingly give up a kidney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Man Says Airline Stopped Him on Suspicion He Was Trafficking His Children
description: American Airlines has apologized to David Ryan Harris, a Black musician who said he and his biracial children were confronted by an airline employee and police officers after a flight last month.
content: American Airlines has apologized to a Black musician who said that he was stopped on suspicion that he was trafficking his own children, who are biracial, on a flight last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Introducing Nathan Lane, the Hip New Face of A24
description: With roles in “Dicks: The Musical” and “Beau Is Afraid,” the stage star is now a repertory player for the hot film company. “Who would have guessed?” he says.
content: When you’re pondering actors associated with the indie-film company A24, your thoughts may run to the young, hot and impossibly tousled.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Downfall of Kevin McCarthy, ‘a Tragic Figure’
description: Readers express their views about the ousted speaker and how the Democrats should have voted. Also: Banned Books Week; tossing food at children.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Chaos in Washington Adds to Market Jitters
description: Stocks and bonds have tumbled worldwide, with the 30-year Treasury bill hitting a 16-year high. Investors are worried about the economy’s health.
content: A far-right mutiny on Capitol Hill has sent markets into a tailspin. Skittish investors have dumped stocks and bonds this morning on fears that chaos in the Republican Party will cause a government shutdown next month and all but squash the fleeting hopes of a soft-landing economic recovery heading into an election year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Maren Morris: The (Deluxe) Interview
description: The country-pop singer discusses her recent decision to step back from country music because of Nashville’s poor track record of tolerance and diversity.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, features an interview with the country star Maren Morris, discussing:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Haiti, Desperate for Peace, Turns to Police Notorious for Violence
description: Police officers from Kenya are being dispatched to bring order to gang-ravaged Haiti, but in their own home country, they have been accused of brutality.
content: The Kenyan force tasked with leading a mission to take back Haiti’s streets from violent gangs that have overtaken much of the country’s capital will be made up of police officers who have a checkered history of their own at home, accused of killing more than 100 people this year and lobbing tear-gas into a school during anti-government demonstrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Katrina Miller
title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry Awarded to 3 Scientists for Exploring the Nanoworld
description: Moungi Bawendi, Louis Brus and Alexei Ekimov developed and discovered quantum dots, particles whose size governs their properties.
content: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded on Wednesday to Moungi G. Bawendi, Louis E. Brus and Alexei I. Ekimov for being pioneers of the nanoworld. The new laureates discovered and developed quantum dots, semiconductors made of particles squeezed so small that their electrons barely have room to breathe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: From a Capitol Hill Basement, Bannon Stokes the Republican Party Meltdown
description: The former Trump adviser has helped create the spectacle of G.O.P. dysfunction, using it to build his own following and those of the right-wing House rebels who took down Kevin McCarthy.
content: On Wednesday morning, two Republicans who hours earlier had toppled Kevin McCarthy as speaker of the House made a well-worn trek to a 19th-century brick townhouse a few blocks away from the Capitol and entered the cluttered sanctuary of Stephen K. Bannon’s recording studio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Francis Issues Urgent Call to Save a Planet Near ‘the Breaking Point’
description: Eight years after his landmark letter on humanity’s obligation to protect the environment, Francis warns that there is still a lot to be done, and quickly.
content: Pope Francis on Wednesday once again implored the world to protect the suffering planet, lamenting in a major new document that scant progress had been made in the eight years since he refocused the Roman Catholic Church more fully on environmental issues in a landmark treatise that catapulted him to the forefront of climate activism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: A Resy Founder Expands His Loyalty Program for Restaurants
description: Ben Leventhal says Blackbird will give many independent restaurants the means to identify and reward regulars for the first time.
content: Ben Leventhal helped found the popular restaurant-news site Eater and the innovative restaurant-reservation service Resy. So a lot of attention has focused on his latest project — Blackbird, the first loyalty platform for independent restaurants — since it began operating in New York City in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Karoun Demirjian
title: Here Are the Republicans Vying to Replace McCarthy as House Speaker
description: The No. 2 Republican and the chairman of the Judiciary Committee appear to be in the strongest positions in the early stages of the sprint to choose a new speaker.
content: Within hours of Representative Kevin McCarthy’s removal as speaker of the House, the race among Republicans to succeed him was on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Petriello
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsea Leu
title: Life Is Boring. Lydia Davis’s New Book Makes That Fascinating.
description: In the author’s latest collection, “Our Strangers,” quotidian situations are stripped down to come alive.
content: A Lydia Davis story, as we’ve come to know it over the course of five decades and seven collections, is a feat of omission. Often no longer than a page, sometimes laid out like poetry, it captures some quotidian situation with nearly all the context stripped out so that, unbound by any definite place or time, it becomes charismatically strange. “How long the shadow is,/coming across the counter,/from this grain of salt,” Davis writes in “Late Afternoon,” featured in her new collection, “Our Strangers.” The image, diminutive and universal, neatly encapsulates the whole endeavor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: The Moomins Live in Peace. Their Creator Tried to Do the Same.
description: A new exhibition in Paris explores how Tove Jansson imagined a kind world that reflected her values as a lesbian artist and ardent pacifist.
content: Europe was on the brink of World War II when Tove Jansson, the Scandinavian writer and artist, sat down to sketch her first “Moomin” story, about a snout-nosed troll living in a magical land threatened by a rising flood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti
title: Democrats Tell Biden Saudi-Israel Pact Needs Concessions for Palestinians
description: The demands would likely be met with stiff resistance from hard-line members of the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
content: Democratic senators told President Biden on Wednesday that any diplomatic pact between Saudi Arabia and Israel would need to include a commitment from Israel to halt settlements in Palestinian territories and preserve “the option of a two-state solution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Our Vacation Destination Has a Poor Human Rights Record. Should We Go?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to travel to a country ruled by an oppressive regime.
content: My husband and I are now retired and are looking forward to making some long-postponed, once-in-a-lifetime trips. Unfortunately, the country at the very top of our bucket list has an authoritarian government and a poor human rights record. We’re finding it difficult to evaluate the cost/benefit of our possible travel there. Our tourism dollars would directly support the local tourism industry and the people who rely on it for their livelihoods. But we’re concerned that it would indirectly support the regime in power, as well. How do we evaluate the ethical implications? — Laura R.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Moity
title: Bedbugs: Vacation Without an Infestation
description: Paris is the latest city where the pests have caused a panic among travelers. Here’s how to keep bedbugs from coming home with you, wherever you go.
content: The talk of Paris Fashion Week this year has been the little, brown bug — bedbugs. The pests have popped up in trains, airports and movie theaters, fanning fears that they may also be lurking in hotels, an echo of New York City’s mid-2000s bedbug panic. The cities and decades may be different, but the scourge is eternal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Make a Choice
description: Gary Larson’s puzzle gives us options.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — It’s fitting that Sam Corbin and I did a switcheroo today, isn’t it? She wrote my usual Saturday post last weekend, and I got to take on a wacky, letter-swapping Wednesday grid by Gary Larson. This is an unusual construction, and there are multiple ways to solve the puzzle correctly.  I was wholly confused for at least the first third, and didn’t fully realize the extent of the theme entries until the cat was out of the bag (or the box, since it’s almost like a Schrödinger grid, although those have single clues for multiple entries).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer and Maggie Haberman
title: Giuliani’s Drinking, Long a Fraught Subject, Has Trump Prosecutors’ Attention
description: The former mayor’s drinking has become an investigative subplot in Donald Trump’s federal case over 2020 election interference. But long before that, friends had grown deeply concerned.
content: Rudolph W. Giuliani had always been hard to miss at the Grand Havana Room, a magnet for well-wishers and hangers-on at the Midtown cigar club that still treated him like the king of New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisa Gabbert
title: Terrance Hayes’s Poems and Essays Sing in Harmony
description: The essays in “Watch Your Language” are in close conversation with the poems in “So to Speak,” letting Hayes play with form and ideas.
content: “Do questions or answers create history?” Terrance Hayes asks in WATCH YOUR LANGUAGE: Visual and Literary Reflections on a Century of American Poetry (Penguin, 214 pp., paperback, $20), a new book of essays, illustrations and prose experiments released simultaneously with a collection of poems, SO TO SPEAK (Penguin Poets, 90 pp., paperback, $20). The question is No. 199 in a list of 255 that appear beside a timeline of 20th-century events interspersed throughout the book. These events were important either for history (1929: “Stock market crash”) or for poetry (1930: “Hart Crane publishes ‘The Bridge’”) — or do these come to the same thing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: This Dance About Refugees Has Flow and a Groove
description: Olivier Tarpaga’s “Once the dust settles, the flowers bloom” is a subtle work of beauty and mystery.
content: Not long ago, the choreographer and musician Olivier Tarpaga, who teaches at Princeton University, wanted to visit the city of his birth and his father’s grave in the north of Burkina Faso. But the region had been overrun by violent jihadists, and he learned that his hometown was now home to a refugee camp for women and children. Instead of visiting, he made a dance theater work about refugees: “Once the dust settles, flowers bloom.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: ‘Our Language Is Dying’
description: The struggle to save Gagauz, a Turkic tongue used by dwindling numbers of people in an ethnic enclave of Moldova, reflects the emotional power of language loyalties across the former Soviet Union.
content: He has published collections of poetry, written more than 20 books, as well as plays, translated works by foreign literary giants like Moliere and is rated as a master of his native language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany, Matthew Goldstein and J. Edward Moreno
title: ‘Lied to the World’ or Acted in ‘Good Faith’: Sam Bankman-Fried’s Trial Opens
description: Prosecutors said the FTX founder had lied to customers. Defense lawyers said he had just been trying to prevent his cryptocurrency exchange from melting down.
content: Federal prosecutors on Wednesday opened the criminal trial of Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the failed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, with a simple message: He deliberately “lied to the world,” leading to one of the biggest financial frauds of a generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Top Art Investor Amassed a Big Collection. Now He’s Selling.
description: Liu Yiqian made global headlines in 2014 and 2015 by paying top prices for paintings and antiquities but is starting to liquidate part of his collection.
content: Few Chinese art collectors have made a bigger splash at global auctions in the past decade than Liu Yiqian, a former Shanghai taxi driver who amassed a fortune through big bets on Chinese real estate and pharmaceutical stocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Leaderless House Faces Trouble Ahead
description: Also, health care workers go on strike. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: After a historic vote to remove Kevin McCarthy from the speakership, House Republicans agreed last night to spend the next week without a formal leader. That means that no votes will be held, no legislation will be passed and the House of Representatives will be effectively powerless until a new speaker is elected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Make the Audio in Your Projects Sound Better
description: The right hardware and software — combined with time to learn — can improve the soundtrack in your videos, podcasts and other creative endeavors.
content: Tired of tinny sound, echoes, inaudible dialogue or just bad audio in your home recording efforts? The popularity of social-media video and podcasts has led to a variety of affordable microphones, software and other tools for creating better-quality audio for personal projects. Even if you don’t plan to start a podcast, understanding digital audio a bit more can make other tasks like recording Grandma’s stories for a family-history archive or adding a narration track to your vacation videos sound much cleaner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
title: After Third Major Shooting in Four Years, Thailand Debates How to Stem Gun Violence
description: Thai citizens, officials and visitors were left reeling from a deadly shooting at a popular mall in Bangkok, and asking what a nation with one of Asia’s highest rates of gun ownership can do.
content: The fatal shooting by a 14-year-old in a popular Bangkok mall set off anguished soul-searching over Thailand’s gun culture on Wednesday, a day after the third high-profile shooting spree in nearly four years killed two people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: City of Light or City of Bites? France Tries to Ease Bedbug Anxiety.
description: With less than a year to go before millions are expected in Paris for the Olympics, a wave of widely publicized reports of bedbug infestations has put French authorities under pressure.
content: In France’s lower house of Parliament, a top opposition lawmaker held up a small vial for all her colleagues to see. Its contents, she warned in a fiery speech this week, were “spreading despair” around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre Espérance
title: Haiti Doesn’t Need More Guns. It Needs a New Government.
description: The U.N. approved sending a multinational security force to tackle Haiti’s gang crisis. What the nation really needs is a new government.
content: Years ago, I was part of a team set up under the auspices of the United Nations to vet new police officers in Haiti. We worked to create a professional force that would protect Haitians and purge it of officers connected to the neighborhood gangs that were mugging and kidnapping people for ransom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: FIFA Will Host 2030 World Cup on Three Continents
description: Soccer’s biggest event will celebrate its centenary by placing games in South America, Europe and Africa. The decision could pave the way for Saudi Arabia to host in 2034.
content: Soccer’s World Cup will be staged in six countries on three continents in its centenary edition in 2030, an unexpected and complex alteration to its traditional format that was approved on Wednesday in a meeting of FIFA’s governing council.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin and John Yoon
title: 5 People Injured in Shooting at Morgan State University in Baltimore
description: The victims, including four students, were being treated for non-life-threatening gunshot wounds. The university canceled or postponed all homecoming events.
content: The authorities in Baltimore on Wednesday said they had not located any suspects or made any arrests after five people, including four students, were shot and injured on the Morgan State University campus on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: When the Phone Rings and the Voice Says: You’ve Won a MacArthur Award
description: On Wednesday, 20 Americans, all anonymously nominated, were recognized by the MacArthur Foundation with $800,000 fellowships often referred to as the “genius” award.
content: Patrick Makuakane, a hula choreographer in San Francisco, was at the Burning Man festival when he received a text from someone who claimed to be from the MacArthur Foundation and had been trying to reach him. The spotty cell service in the Black Rock Desert in Nevada made Makuakane miss the calls, and he did not understand why he was being contacted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: This Is Why Trump Keeps Antagonizing the Judge in His Fraud Trial
description: He’s not just seeking publicity. He’s laying the groundwork for his eventual appeal — and for 2024.
content: It’s not surprising that Donald Trump viciously insults Letitia James, the New York State attorney general who has taken him to court. What is a little surprising is that he keeps bashing the judge who is trying him, to the point of saying he should be disbarred. He also attacked the judge’s law clerk, earning him a stern warning. You don’t tug on Superman’s cape, you don’t spit into the wind and you don’t — I would think — defy and needle the very person who holds your financial fate in his hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Justices Hear Civil Rights Dispute About Disability Activist
description: The arguments focused on whether the activist, Deborah Laufer, has the right to sue a Maine hotel, even though she did not plan to stay there.
content: The Supreme Court wrangled on Wednesday over the question of whether a disability rights activist could sue a hotel for violating a federal disability law, even if she never planned to stay there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Hosts Roast Kevin McCarthy on His Way Out
description: “Nine months? I’ve been to Phish concerts longer than that,” Jimmy Fallon joked of McCarthy’s tenure as speaker of the House.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Marge Locker
title: 1960s London Comes Alive in a Fierce, Funny Coming-of-Age Novel
description: In “The Halt During the Chase,” by Rosemary Tonks — first published in 1972, and newly reissued — a young woman goes in search of herself.
content: From the first page of this clever, fishy little novel, our narrator, Sophie, is the kind of woman whose laughter is a weapon. She could scare off an assailant with one well-timed whack of her tongue. Originally published in 1972, “The Halt During the Chase” is the second Rosemary Tonks novel to be reissued by New Directions in as many years, bringing a new audience to her charming and imperfect heroines, who are all voice, half poetry and half snarl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Ripples of Republican Chaos
description: Republicans’ impulses to disrupt and destroy keep winning out.
content: This week, Donald Trump delivered his version of a sad tiny desk performance, hunched over the defendant’s table in a New York courtroom, diminished and watching the illusion of power and grandeur he has sold voters thin and run like oil in a hot pan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: The Downfall of Kevin McCarthy
description: For the first time in the history of the House of Representatives, its members fired their leader in the middle of a term.
content: In the 234-year history of the House of Representatives, its members had never voted to fire their leader in the middle of a term. They did so yesterday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Maryland Supreme Court to Hear Arguments in Adnan Syed Case
description: His conviction received national attention after it was the subject of the “Serial” podcast’s first season in 2014. The victim’s brother is seeking a new hearing regarding Mr. Syed’s conviction.
content: The Maryland Supreme Court is expected to hear arguments on Thursday morning in the long-running case of Adnan Syed, the subject of the podcast “Serial” who has spent more than 23 years fighting charges that he killed his high school girlfriend, Hae Min Lee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Rishi Sunak Cancels a Rail Project to Build an Image
description: The British prime minister embraced a more divisive profile, casting himself as a disrupter and scrapping part of the High Speed 2 line that predecessors had championed.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain, taking the stage at his first Conservative Party conference as leader on Wednesday, sought to cast himself as a change agent who would rebuild his economically depleted country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: At ‘Jaja’s,’ Where Everybody Knows Your Mane
description: Jocelyn Bioh’s Broadway playwriting debut, set in a Harlem hair braiding shop, is a hot and hilarious workplace sitcom.
content: Nothing says comedy to me like hot pink, and pink doesn’t get much hotter than the pink of the house curtain that greets you at the beginning of “Jaja’s African Hair Braiding” by Jocelyn Bioh. In the pale and staid Samuel J. Friedman Theater, a fuchsia drop depicting dozens of elaborately woven hairstyles — micro braids, cornrows, “kinky twists” and more — tells you, along with the bouncy Afro-pop music, to prepare for laughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: What Can Patrick McHenry, the Interim Speaker, Do?
description: Representative Patrick T. McHenry of North Carolina, who took the gavel, may oversee the election of a new speaker. But he does not have the power to run the chamber.
content: Moments after the House voted to boot Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, as the speaker, one of his closest confidants, Representative Patrick T. McHenry of North Carolina, stepped up to the dais to take the gavel as the interim speaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong, Ana Ley and Juan Arredondo
title: Turning to Street Vending, New Migrants Find a Competitive World
description: Newly arrived migrants are hawking candy, fruit and beverages in New York City, often with young children in tow. Turf battles with more established vendors are becoming common.
content: Standing on a subway platform deep below Times Square, Natalí Tualombo, a newly arrived migrant from Ecuador, sold water bottles and sodas from a cooler, her 4-year-old son sitting at her feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Krayzie Bone of Bone Thugs-N-Harmony Posts About His Health Crisis
description: “Never take life for granted enjoy it while you have it!” the rapper wrote on social media. He posted a picture from a hospital, saying he had been in a nine-day fight for his life.
content: Krayzie Bone, a member of Bone Thugs-N-Harmony, one of the most influential rap groups in history, has been fighting for his life for several days, he said in a post on social media on Monday that included a photo of him in a hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: With the Writers’ Strike Over, ‘Saturday Night Live’ Will Soon Return
description: Pete Davidson — who left the cast of the show in 2022 — will host the season premiere on Oct. 14.
content: With the five-month writers’ strike ending last week, a certain corner of television is coming back to life: first with the return of the late night shows on Monday, and now with “Saturday Night Live,” which will kick off its 49th season on Oct. 14, the show announced Wednesday on X, formerly known as Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Facing Cancellation, Halloween Dog Festival Gets a Formal Parade Route
description: Organizers of the annual parade in New York’s Tompkins Square Park nearly canceled the event over permitting and funding issues. Now it’s back and bigger than ever.
content: It’s hard to say which New Yorkers love more — Halloween or their dogs. For more than 30 years, those two passions have converged at the Tompkins Square Halloween Dog Parade, as canines have transformed into charcuterie boards, celebrities, Jesus and even bodega cats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Climate Change Is a Key Obstacle for New York City’s Transit System
description: The M.T.A. released a report on Wednesday that aimed to detail the greatest needs over the next two decades of the city’s aging transit system.
content: Transit officials in New York on Wednesday released a list of the system’s most pressing needs that ranks contending with climate change among the top priorities for the subway and bus network, which was paralyzed last week by a torrential storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Skydiving
description: How adventurous are you?
content: How adventurous are you? Do you seek out new experiences, thrills and challenges, or are you happier with more familiar and safer activities?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Eileen Sullivan
title: Blinken Travels to Mexico Amid Rising Tension Over Border, Drug Trafficking
description: The meeting is an opportunity to ease an increasingly tense relationship between two allies, while addressing hot-button issues in the 2024 presidential race in the United States.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and other top Biden administration officials traveled to Mexico City on Wednesday hoping to bolster a strategy to confront staggering fentanyl overdoses in the United States and soaring migration in the Western Hemisphere.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Dying Turkic Tongue and the Quest to Keep It Alive
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 5, 2023.
content: “There is no future for small languages. The future belongs to big languages — English, Russian, Chinese and Turkish.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa M. Hamilton
title: The Taste of Home in a Grain of Rice
description: When people in Fresno load Ia’s rice into their steamers, the aroma that fills the kitchen offers a nourishment more vital than food: home.
content: Throughout September, Ia’s phone rings off the hook. “What is it?” she answers. But she already knows. The rest of the year, her customers are satisfied with rice from the store. In autumn, though, people call day and night for the chance to buy the rice that she grows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: A Trial in Trump’s Georgia Elections Case Will Start Soon — Without Trump
description: Two lawyers who tried to help overturn the 2020 election results are facing trial this month, an early test of the Georgia case against the former president and 17 others.
content: Within weeks, jury selection in Fulton County, Ga. will be underway. Cameras will be in the courtroom. And prosecutors will present their case alleging a sprawling conspiracy to overturn the 2020 election results in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: What the Kaiser Permanente Strike Means for Patients
description: Especially in California, people could experience delays in appointments or test results and even have medical procedures postponed after thousands of health care workers walked out.
content: Tens of thousands of Kaiser Permanente workers, including pharmacists, lab technicians, therapists and housekeepers, went on strike Wednesday morning. Kaiser patients in California, Colorado, Oregon, Virginia and Washington State, where Kaiser health care workers are walking out, will be affected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Luke Broadwater
title: Scalise and Jordan Announce Bids for Speaker as Vacancy Paralyzes the House
description: Representatives Steve Scalise of Louisiana and Jim Jordan of Ohio are both running to succeed Kevin McCarthy, who was ousted as speaker.
content: The second-ranking House Republican and the chairman of the Judiciary Committee on Wednesday both announced their campaigns for speaker, setting the stage for a bruising struggle pitting some of the most conservative G.O.P. leaders against one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Moises Velasquez-Manoff
title: The Mystery of My Burning Esophagus
description: As a science writer, I’ve spent years covering the rise of allergic conditions. Why couldn’t I figure out my own?
content: My year of torment began with a brutal headache. The pain came on gradually over several weeks, as if some part of my brain were being slowly squeezed in a vise. Darkness lapped at the edge of my vision. Over-the-counter painkillers didn’t help. Occasionally, a dementia-like loss of vocabulary struck, often when I was talking to people over the phone. I found myself unable to recall easy things like “Washington, D.C.” or “George Clooney.” I’d end up staring at my computer without any inkling of what I’d sat down to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: G.O.P. Candidates Split Over Kevin McCarthy’s Ouster as House Speaker
description: Several Republicans in the presidential field had endorsed a government shutdown, at odds with Mr. McCarthy.
content: The ouster of Representative Kevin McCarthy as House speaker on Tuesday exposed sharp divisions among the Republican presidential field, with at least one candidate saying that the power move by right-wing caucus members had been warranted — but others bemoaned the turmoil, and some stayed silent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Biden Cancels an Additional $9 Billion in Student Loan Debt
description: The move comes just three days after student loan repayments resumed following a three-year pause.
content: President Biden canceled an additional $9 billion in student debt on Wednesday as repayments started up again this month after a three-year pause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: ‘The Confessions’ Review: A Mother’s Tale, Told With Empathy and Care
description: A new play by Alexander Zeldin recreates his mother’s winding, painful path to a life of her own.
content: Minutes into “The Confessions,” a new production by the British playwright and director Alexander Zeldin, the main character, Alice, says demurely, “See, I’m not interesting. I have nothing of interest to tell.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Lawyers Expand Legal Fight for Longest-Held Prisoner of War on Terrorism
description: Abu Zubaydah was the first prisoner waterboarded by the C.I.A. He has never faced charges at Guantánamo Bay.
content: Lawyers for the longest-held prisoner in the U.S. war against terrorism have begun a new legal offensive in multiple courts aimed at securing his release from Guantánamo Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Russian Journalist Sentenced in Absentia for Antiwar Protest
description: Marina Ovsyannikova, who worked for state TV for two decades before protesting Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, was sentenced to more than eight years.
content: A former Russian state television journalist who staged an on-air protest after the Kremlin launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine was sentenced in absentia on Wednesday to eight and a half years in a prison colony on charges of spreading false information about Russia’s army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: James Jorden, Creator of an Essential Opera Blog, Dies at 69
description: With Parterre Box, he brought together high culture, punk aesthetics and gleeful camp in an irreverent source for news, criticism and gossip.
content: James Jorden, a feisty, influential writer and editor who brought together high culture, punk aesthetics and gleeful camp in his opera zine-turned-website Parterre Box, was found dead on Monday at his home in Sunnyside, Queens. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Teachers Can’t Hold Students Accountable. It’s Making the Job Miserable.
description: And it’s damaging a generation.
content: A few weeks ago, I wrote about how America’s teacher pipeline is drying up. According to education researchers, the proportion of college graduates who go into teaching is at a 50-year low. Yes, there are still college graduates and young professionals willing to commit to a challenging career that frequently comes with low pay, but that pool shrinks when you factor in mountainous student debt, declining respect for teachers and the reality that schools are ground zero for the culture wars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Lauren Herstik
title: Judge Appoints a Conservator to Oversee Affairs of Former Supreme
description: Cindy Birdsong’s family had sought to govern her affairs, but a Los Angeles judge gave control to the local Office of the Public Guardian, at least for now.
content: A judge in Los Angeles on Wednesday ordered that Cindy Birdsong, an 83-year-old former member of the Supremes, be put under a temporary conservatorship in which county officials would oversee her care and finances following a dispute over who has rightful legal control over her affairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: I Sodi Returns, Without the Sardine-Can Space
description: The popular Tuscan outpost in the West Village has moved to more generous quarters, but the bracing minimalism of its cooking remains largely intact.
content: From 2008 until she moved to larger quarters this year, Rita Sodi served plainspoken Tuscan cooking in her plainspoken restaurant on Christopher Street, I Sodi. The dining room was as tightly packed as the coach section of a sold-out flight on Thanksgiving weekend, and it could be difficult to get in or out of your seat without accidentally becoming intimate with a stranger at the next table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evelyn Clark
title: It’s Time to Rethink the Americans With Disabilities Act
description: The Justice Department should do more to enforce the law.
content: The Supreme Court on Wednesday will hear a case that could shape the future of the Americans With Disabilities Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: The Director of ‘Savior Complex’ on the Perils of ‘White Saviorism’
description: Jackie Jesko spoke about the subject of her HBO docu-series, a Christian missionary accused of playing doctor with the lives of Ugandan children.
content: Renee Bach was 19 when she felt God calling her to move to Uganda, where in 2009 she founded a Christian mission to serve hungry children. Home-schooled in a Baptist family, she had always been taught that when God calls, you follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York City Moves to Suspend Right-to-Shelter Mandate
description: The request is part of a monthslong legal battle over the city’s obligation to provide housing for thousands of migrants.
content: Mayor Eric Adams is seeking to suspend New York City’s longstanding obligation to provide shelter to anyone who asks for it, as officials struggle to find housing for thousands of migrants arriving from the southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Tracey Tully and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Inside the Menendez Indictment: A Mercedes and a Secretive Fatal Crash
description: A 2018 fatal car crash in Bogota, N.J., drew no media attention and resulted in no charges. The driver was the soon-to-be wife of Senator Robert Menendez.
content: It was a cold evening in December 2018, and Nadine Arslanian, the soon-to-be wife of Senator Robert Menendez, was zipping through the darkened streets of suburban New Jersey in a black Mercedes-Benz sedan. She would later tell the police she did not see the man stepping out in front of her to cross a busy thoroughfare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson
title: The 8-Year-Old Boy at the Heart of a Fight Over Tibetan Buddhism
description: He may have to defend the faith in Mongolia against pressure from China’s ruling Communist Party.
content: The boy had seemed destined for a life of affluence and earthly pursuits. Born into the family behind a major mining conglomerate in Mongolia, he might have been picked to someday lead the company from its steel-and-glass headquarters in the country’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: McCarthy Is Ousted, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Garry Hynes Brings Sean O’Casey’s Dublin Trilogy to Life
description: At NYU Skirball, Druid’s marathon production depicts the beginning of a free Irish state through the voices of the working class.
content: In the back room of a hotel cafe in Lower Manhattan, the Irish director Garry Hynes was talking about Sean O’Casey, the laborer turned playwright whose frequently funny, sometimes blood-chilling, canonical 1920s tragicomedies are set amid the tenements of Dublin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: A Ransom Note and a Fingerprint: How a Missing 9-Year-Old Was Found
description: The rescue of Charlotte Sena began with a lucky break — and a possible missed opportunity — followed by old-fashioned police work.
content: It was 4:20 a.m., long before dawn on Monday, when a driver approached the house of a missing girl in upstate New York, placing a note in the black mailbox before darting off through a dark spider web of country roads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Gerontocracy Explains the Matt Gaetz Clown Show
description: Chaotic debates over fiscal policy are part of what you get when a democracy becomes a gerontocracy.
content: You can analyze the circus in the House of Representatives in terms of personalities (the bland ambition of Kevin McCarthy colliding with the antic, made-for-television career of Matt Gaetz) or in terms of the nature of the Republican coalition (united only by anti-liberalism and rabble-rousing, and therefore held hostage to the most shameless rabble-rouser).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Hi, ‘Barbie’! Russian Theaters Find Ways to Screen Blockbusters Amid Sanctions.
description: American studios stopped releasing Hollywood movies in Russia after the invasion of Ukraine, but many theaters have found a workaround.
content: As people in much of the world flocked to see Greta Gerwig’s blockbuster film “Barbie” this summer, viewers in Russia were left out. At least officially.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: It’s Time to Pay Your Student Loans. What Happens if You Fall Behind?
description: Missed payments will be reported as a forbearance rather than as delinquencies. But your credit score could still be affected.
content: With federal student loan payments due again for the first time in nearly four years, financially stretched borrowers may be concerned about the consequences of missed payments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich, John Vincler, Max Lakin, Travis Diehl, Jillian Steinhauer, Aruna D'Souza, Arthur Lubow and Blake Gopnik
title: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in October
description: Want to see new art in New York this weekend? Check out “Chopped & Screwed” at White Cube on the Upper East Side or see figures by Rita and France-Lise McGurn in TriBeCa. And don’t miss Tetsuya Ishida’s finely rendered nightmares in Chelsea.
content: Want to see new art in New York this weekend? Check out “Chopped & Screwed” at White Cube on the Upper East Side or see figures by Rita and France-Lise McGurn in TriBeCa. And don’t miss Tetsuya Ishida’s finely rendered nightmares in Chelsea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanore Park
title: Our Favorite Restaurants in San Francisco
description: The New York Times is sharing its current choices, including world-class Korean barbecue, Mission-style burritos and quintessential California cuisine.
content: Where’s the best place to eat?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Fisherman Convicted in Plot to Sell $900,000 of Illegal Fluke and Bass
description: Chris Winkler, a fisherman based in Montauk, N.Y., was accused of falsifying records to sell over-quota fish.
content: A Montauk, N.Y., fisherman accused of vastly exceeding legal limits on how much fluke he could bring ashore was convicted on all charges in a federal court in Central Islip on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Georgia Dullea, 90, Dies; Reporter Chronicled a Changing Society
description: Writing for The Times with a gimlet eye, she examined the impact of no-fault divorces on women, the excesses of the Reagan years, the AIDS crisis, and more.
content: Georgia Dullea, a style reporter for The New York Times who chronicled, with sly bemusement and a miniaturist’s eye for detail, three decades of a culture in transition, died on Sunday in the Bronx. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: A Spike Lee Joint via Movie Posters and Sports Jerseys
description: Lee, the director of “Do the Right Thing” and “Malcolm X,” provided more than 400 items for a Brooklyn Museum exhibition.
content: The first image to catch your eye in the Brooklyn Museum’s new exhibition about the director Spike Lee could be a wall projection of “Malcolm X,” the 1992 movie staring Denzel Washington. Nearby hang artworks of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Trayvon Martin, whose killing inspired the Black Lives Matter Movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell
title: A ‘Shadow’ Lending Market in the U.S., Funded by Insurance Premiums
description: Apollo was the first to use annuities to build a major financing business. Others followed, driving the growth of the private lending market and worrying regulators.
content: In 2009, as the banking business was on the verge of being reshaped by new regulations in the wake of the great financial crisis, the private equity giant Apollo Global Management found a way to make money off the retirement savings of millions of everyday Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Hans Buetow, Christina Djossa, Jen Poyant, Larissa Anderson, Corey Schreppel, Carole Sabouraud, Marion Lozano and Dan Powell
title: Have You Ever Kept a Secret From Your Wife?
description: For years, Khalid Abdulqaadir hid his past from his wife. To try and save their relationship, he had to tell her the truth.
content: Khalid Abdulqaadir’s life was full of secrets. He started keeping them when he was a teenager, after his father was accused of an unimaginable crime. He didn’t want to explain his family history every time he started a new relationship. So his secrets followed him, even as he got married.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Our Flag Means Death’ Review: Stormy Seas in Season 2
description: An offbeat pirate comedy with a devoted fan base tacks in the direction of romance.
content: This review contains spoilers for the first season of “Our Flag Means Death.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Flood Threats Are Rising. Here’s Where People Are Moving Into Harm’s Way.
description: Rapid development along coasts and rivers has increased flood exposure worldwide, particularly in South and East Asia, a study found.
content: Worldwide, humans now occupy more than twice as much land in flood-prone areas as they did four decades ago, according to a new study in the journal Nature. The findings highlight the degree to which rapid development along coasts and in floodplains has increased the need for disaster preparedness around the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiyun Li
title: How to Raise a ‘Warrior Queen’
description: For 12 years, Yiyun Li taught her writing students a story by Amy Bloom about the power, and limitations, of love. Confronting unbearable grief, she returned to it.
content: In the summer of 2001, seven months pregnant and working in a research lab in Iowa City, I signed up for an eight-week fiction-writing class taught by James Alan McPherson. I turned in my very first short story, “Immortality,” which Jim enthused about in class, though I was too inexperienced to understand his excitement. I told him shyly that I was a scientist but wanted to be a writer. “What do you mean you want to be a writer?” he said. “You are a writer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Most Influential Woman in Fashion
description: How Miuccia Prada — and Miu Miu — became the muse of the season. Plus a detour through Chanel and Louis Vuitton.
content: Want to know what you will wear next?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes
title: Actress Julia Ormond Accuses Harvey Weinstein of Battery in Lawsuit
description: Ms. Ormond also sued Creative Artists Agency, which represented her at the time, and Disney, which owned Mr. Weinstein’s Miramax.
content: The actress Julia Ormond, known for “Legends of the Fall” and “Sabrina,” accused Harvey Weinstein of sexual battery in a lawsuit filed on Wednesday in a New York court, claiming that the former film producer forced her to give him oral sex during a business meeting in 1995.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: A Death Row Opera Goes to Sing Sing, With Inmates Onstage
description: Metropolitan Opera stars joined prisoners for a one-night-only performance of “Dead Man Walking.”
content: One by one, the inmates filed into a chapel at Sing Sing Correctional Facility in Ossining, N.Y. — past a line of security officers, past a sign reading, “Open wide the door to Christ.” Under stained-glass windows, they formed a circle, introducing themselves to a crowd of visitors as composers, rappers, painters and poets. Then they began to sing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa and Leanne Abraham
title: Where’s All the Antarctic Sea Ice? Annual Peak Is the Lowest Ever Recorded.
description: Earlier this year it was clear Antarctic sea ice levels were low. Now, as the continent enters spring, it’s obvious that “it’s a really exceptional year.”
content: Winter is over in the Southern Hemisphere and sea ice around Antarctica has likely grown as much as it’s going to for 2023, according to the National Snow and Ice Data Center. Antarctic sea ice reached its lowest peak by a wide margin for any year since 1979, when the continuous satellite record began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Thursday Briefing: What’s Next After McCarthy’s Downfall
description: Plus an auction of works from China’s top art collector.
content: The ousting of Kevin McCarthy from the role of House Speaker was a historic first that left an entire branch of the U.S. government paralyzed, putting its legislative work on hold until a successor is chosen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas, Jonathan Swan and Shane Goldmacher
title: DeSantis Gets a $15 Million Cash Infusion and Moves Staff to Iowa
description: The relocation caps a monthslong retooling of the campaign, which was in financial dire straits this summer. But the Florida governor still has a steep climb ahead.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is relocating a significant portion of his presidential campaign staff from Tallahassee to Des Moines, according to his top deputies, redeploying his team to the leadoff state after a $15 million fund-raising haul that advisers said had helped stabilize his campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Can’t I Get My Wife to Split the Costs of Sharing Our Home?
description: A retiree is mystified as to why his new wife is willing to pay for her share of groceries and utility bills, but refuses to chip in for property taxes and insurance premiums.
content: I’m as confused as a goat on AstroTurf, and I hope you can help me: My wife and I are retired. We got married a year ago. About two years before that, when we started to get serious about each other, I invited her to move into my home. (I own it, and there’s no mortgage on it.) Since the day she moved in, she has paid half the utilities and grocery bills. But she refuses to pay any of the home maintenance costs, property taxes or insurance premiums because she is not on the deed. In the event of my death, half my estate, including the house, will go to her, and the other half to my adult son. I believe she should pay a portion of the insurance and property taxes. Am I being unreasonable?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: McCarthy’s Extraordinary Downfall Reflects an Ungovernable G.O.P.
description: The glib Californian made many promises and paid a price when he was unable to fulfill them. But his demise also reflected the challenge of wielding a Republican majority that refuses to be governed.
content: Kevin McCarthy did two things right, but too many other things wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Can Anyone Lead House Republicans Out of the Darkness?
description: Mr. Gaetz and his fellow disrupters have done what no other rebel band managed before.
content: Who out there picked nine months in the office betting pool for how long Kevin McCarthy would survive as House speaker? Go ahead. Raise your hands. Looks like you’re due a victory lap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Magpie Earling
title: Read Your Way Through Missoula
description: Montana calls to storytellers: The cold clear waters of its rivers have carried the voices of its inhabitants from time immemorial, says Debra Magpie Earling, one of its writers. Here, she recommends her favorites.
content: Long before white settlement and Lewis and Clark tramped through the area now known as Missoula, the Séliš and Qĺispé buffalo hunters gathered in the place where the Blackfoot and the Clark Fork Rivers meet to plan and reconnoiter, and to tell stories of their dangerous hunts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Draper
title: More Speaker Crisis Fallout: Pelosi Is Evicted From Bonus Office
description: Representative Nancy Pelosi had been given a “hideaway” office suite as a courtesy — one that was rescinded after she did nothing to help Representative Kevin McCarthy.
content: The seething anger from the ouster of Speaker Kevin McCarthy has now spread to highly coveted congressional real estate. Former Speaker Nancy Pelosi has been evicted from her hideaway office in the Capitol by the Republican-controlled House Administration Committee and was ordered to vacate by the close of business on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: The ousting of Speaker Kevin McCarthy.
content: Lawmakers in the U.S. House of Representatives voted 216 to 210 yesterday to remove Speaker Kevin McCarthy from his leadership position. The vote was instigated by a group of hard-line Republican Party members, and it was the first time in modern history of the House of Representatives that such a vote passed. The House speaker is next in line of succession for the presidency after the vice president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Notopoulos
title: The Forrest Gump of Data Mining Saw It All
description: McKenzie Funk’s “The Hank Show” follows the improbable career of one man, and the surveillance state he helped create.
content: If there was a Mount Rushmore of the architects of the modern panopticon state, it might be composed of Meta’s Mark Zuckerberg, the Palantir head Peter Thiel and Hon-Ton That, founder of Clearview AI. But perhaps there should be a fourth, more chiseled visage up there, one you probably don’t recognize: that of Hank Asher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson and Emily Baumgaertner
title: Kaiser Permanente Health Care Workers Begin Strike
description: The health system failed to reach a new contract agreement with many of its unionized employees, who walked off the job in several states.
content: More than 75,000 Kaiser Permanente health care workers began a three-day strike Wednesday, a job action that could delay medical appointments, lab results and prescriptions for thousands of patients, especially in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Alicia Keys Steps Into a New Spotlight
description: “Hell’s Kitchen,” a musical inspired by the singer-songwriter’s teenage years in New York, is set to open Off Broadway.
content: One night this summer, Alicia Keys fell asleep listening to show tunes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Hawthorne
title: Peter Zumthor on Paring Back a ‘Beautiful Idea’ for LACMA
description: The Swiss architect of one of the most polarizing museums in the country says his Los Angeles design has been significantly streamlined. So why have costs kept rising?
content: A list of 10 “Working Rules” is taped to the concrete wall on the top floor of the Swiss architect Peter Zumthor’s studio, which overlooks a dramatic alpine landscape through floor-to-ceiling glass. Rule No. 1: “Have a clear idea of what you want.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $640,000 Homes in Vermont, Missouri and Ohio
description: An 1860 Victorian in Dorset, a 1912 Craftsman house in Kansas City and a renovated 1890 home in Columbus.
content: This house was built as a church rectory, a few blocks from the town hall and a post office. It is less than a five-minute drive from East Dorset Trail, a hiking path that winds along Mad Tom Brook, and less than 10 minutes from the campsites and lakefront beach at Emerald Lake State Park. The closest shopping and dining options, including a Shaw’s grocery store, are about 15 minutes away, in Manchester.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in October
description: “Lupin” returns and the latest literary horror adaptation from Mike Flanagan debuts, just in time for Halloween.
content: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of October’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Hirschfeld
title: Ready to Give Gravel Biking a Try? There’s No Time Like the Fall.
description: There are few better ways to revel in the blaze of autumn leaves than by cycling down out-of-the way dirt or gravel roads and paths. Here are five places to explore on two wheels.
content: You know that feeling of riding a bike as a kid — the freedom to go (almost) anywhere, to explore, to ride with friends? Gravel biking is like that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson
title: Here’s What to Know About Tensions Over Tibetan Buddhism
description: Much centers on the question of who gets to choose the successor of the Dalai Lama when he dies.
content: Tibetan Buddhism has long been led by the Dalai Lama, the 88-year-old spiritual leader who fled Tibet in 1959 and has been living in exile in India ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: In Michigan, Ramaswamy Dives Into Local Dispute Over Chinese Company
description: Vivek Ramaswamy will end his day in Michigan with a rally opposing plans by a Chinese subsidiary to build an electric vehicle battery factory in the state.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy will make a swing through Michigan on Wednesday as he seeks to capture voters in a swing state seen as a battleground for blue-collar workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Emma Bubola
title: Chemistry Nobel Prize Revealed in Media Hours Early
description: Some Swedish news outlets correctly reported the laureates’ names even before the choice was formally signed off, according to the academy that awards the prize.
content: Observers following Wednesday’s announcement of the 2023 Nobel Prize in Chemistry were left dumbfounded — and not just by quantum dots, the subject of the laureates’ research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Washington
title: A Japanese Pancake That Wastes Nothing and Saves Everything
description: Okonomiyaki, special in its simplicity, can be a culinary home of your making.
content: About a decade ago — after an adult sleepover — I had my first bites of okonomiyaki, in a man’s walk-up apartment not far from Osaka’s Namba train station. I’d only just gotten used to the city’s drowsy mornings. My chef, an older guy with even sleepier eyes than mine, had seemingly every ingredient but the one he was looking for, grumbling as he chopped, stirred, ladled and fried our batter. But everything he did have went into the pancakes. And every bite tasted like something else — unexpected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann and Madison Malone Kircher
title: All Your Favorite Movies Are Already on TikTok
description: Paramount tried to make “Mean Girls” happen all over again for a new generation.
content: Cady Heron, the protagonist of the 2004 comedy “Mean Girls,” was the new kid in town once again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Trump Is Excited About These Three Things
description: Will they attract enough voters for him to win?
content: To advance his relentless political ambition, Donald Trump has ridden a promise, a commitment and a pledge.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Harry and Meghan’s Royal Real Estate Woes
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Malitz
title: What’s in Our Queue? Jon Pardi and More
description: I’m a deputy editor on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I’ve been watching, listening to and more.
content: I’m a deputy editor on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I’ve been watching, listening to and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: Remembering Dianne Feinstein
description: Senator Dianne Feinstein, who died last week, lay in state at City Hall in San Francisco on Wednesday. Here's how political leaders and residents honored her.
content: Senator Dianne Feinstein, who died last week, lay in state at City Hall in San Francisco on Wednesday. Here's how political leaders and residents honored her.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Çilbir (Turkish Eggs With Yogurt) Recipe
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rose Maura Lorre
title: Extend Your Jack-o’-Lantern’s Life
description: Tips to help your jack-o'-lantern stick around.
content: Tips to help your jack-o'-lantern stick around.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Police Question Bob Menendez’s Future Wife After Fatal Car Crash
description: Dashcam video from 2018 obtained by The New York Times shows police officers in New Jersey speaking to Nadine Arslanian, Senator Bob Menendez’s soon-to-be wife, after she struck a man with her car.
content: Dashcam video from 2018 obtained by The New York Times shows police officers in New Jersey speaking to Nadine Arslanian, Senator Bob Menendez’s soon-to-be wife, after she struck a man with her car.
source.name: The New York Times
